metadata.name: A Spotty Situation
metadata.description:
The day I dropped my lens cap next to a wild leopard! üò±üòÖü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è  
*****  
Honey the leopard had a fresh kill, and was contently feasting on the guts of a baby oryx when we found her.

Click, click, click‚Ä¶ our camera shutters were on overdrive. It was the first time I‚Äôd seen a wild leopard feasting on a fresh kill. 

Great! I was happy with my close up shots, and went to grab my wider lens to get more of the surroundings in shot.

But arghhhhhh!!! My clumsy fingers somehow managed to both unscrew the lens cap, and also simultaneously flick it off the side of the Land Rover. 

Oops. Sorrryyyyyyy‚Ä¶..

The lens cap landed about a metre from the vehicle, right in front of Honey, who was just another metre away. 

She noticed, and looked up from her meal. 

I held my breath as she got up to explore what this little plastic thing was. 

She sniffed it, looked around, growled a little‚Ä¶ all as we stayed as silent and as still as possible.

What was going to happen next? No one knew, but we all just watched and waited.

Honey then sat down next to us and continued to check us out. 
As slowly and silently as possible, I hit record on my phone, and caught her as she growled at us.

*****  
Our guide, Carel, later told us that this was the closest a wild leopard has ever come to a vehicle. 

Not only that, but this was also the ONLY time he‚Äôs ever broken out in a sweat in his entire career as a guide. 

So my lens cap is gone for good (no we didn‚Äôt try and get it back), but wow, what an experience for us! üòÆ‚Äçüí®

Taken in Namibia
